Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you ever been gazing at a starry sky when suddenly 
a bright dot glided into view? If it wasn't blinking, then you've had
the distinct pleasure of seeing one of mankind's greatest 
collaborative feats with your own eyes: The International Space Station. Roughly the size of six-bedroom house,
and weighing more than 320 cars, the International Space Station 
is so large that no single rocket could have 
lifted it into orbit. Instead, it was assembled piece by piece while hurtling through space
at 28,000 kilometers per hour, lapping the Earth once every 90 minutes. It all started when sixteen nations signed the Space Station 
Intergovernmental Agreement, laying out each partner's 
expected contributions to the ISS, from modules and maintenance
to sharing information and finances. At an estimated 100 billion U.S. dollars, the Space Station would be
the most expensive object ever built. The whole world watched as a Russian rocket launched 
the first module of the ISS into the sky. Zarya, meaning sunrise, 
was equipped with two solar panels and a propulsion system 
that had the important task of keeping the young station 
from crashing into the Earth by staying a safe 400 kilometers away. The U.S. Space Shuttle Endeavour
followed two weeks later carrying Unity, a node module to which
other modules could be connected, and an international 
six-person assembly crew. Then came Zvezda, which brought
communications and living accommodations. Ever since the International 
Space Station's first tenants arrived, it's been continually occupied with more than 200 visitors spending 
an average of six months on board. Astronaut Samantha Cristoforetti 
holds the record for the longest single space flight
by a woman at 199 days on the ISS. 2001 saw the arrival of Destiny,
the first of four research modules, where astronauts spend
approximately 36 hours a week conducting extraordinary experiments
in microgravity. Their schedules are packed with exercise, two hours a day to fend off 
muscle atrophy, station maintenance and repair, and connecting with family 
or awe-inspired minds around the world. But they still find time for fun,
with regular movie nights and even shooting 
the first music video in space. Destiny also controls the seven-jointed
robotic Canadarm2. Capable of moving 
more than 100,000 kilograms, it's perfect for unloading 
new arrivals from shuttles. 2001 was a busy year for the Space Station
with the addition of Quest, the main airlock for strolls outside, and Pirs, a pier for Russian 
spacecrafts to dock including the ever-ready 
emergency escape vehicle, Soyuz. Then, on February 1st, 2003, after delivering 
research modules to the ISS, the space shuttle
Columbia exploded during reentry tragically killing 
the seven-member crew on board. After a four-year hiatus, work quickly
picked up pace with the addition of more hubs, 
airlocks, docks, and an observation cupola for stunning
360-degree views of our world and beyond. Other critical components included 
platforms and trusses to support radiators that direct all the heat generated
by the station's electronics into space and solar panels that are efficient enough
to power 55 homes. It took ten years and over 30 missions, but finally, the International 
Space Station was complete, coinciding with the U.S. Space 
Shuttle Program's retirement. The Space Station continues to serve
as an incredible model for international collaboration. This year, two people 
began a one-year stay on the ISS, allowing scientists to study the long-term
physical and psychological effects of being in space, which would prove useful for increasingly
ambitious space travel, like trips to Mars. Over its lifetime, we've learned 
an immense amount scientifically, but also about 
our capacity to work together and accomplish truly remarkable acts.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: About how big is the International Space Station?
Options: A. Roughly the size of a 3-bedroom house, B. Roughly the size of a 5-bedroom house, C. Roughly the size of a 4-bedroom house, D. Roughly the size of a 6-bedroom house
Correct Option: D

Have you ever been gazing at a starry sky when suddenly 
a bright dot glided into view? If it wasn't blinking, then you've had
the distinct pleasure of seeing one of mankind's greatest 
collaborative feats with your own eyes: The International Space Station. Roughly the size of six-bedroom house,
and weighing more than 320 cars, the International Space Station 
is so large that no single rocket could have 
lifted it into orbit. Instead, it was assembled piece by piece while hurtling through space
at 28,000 kilometers per hour, lapping the Earth once every 90 minutes. It all started when sixteen nations signed the Space Station 
Intergovernmental Agreement, laying out each partner's 
expected contributions to the ISS, from modules and maintenance
to sharing information and finances. At an estimated 100 billion U.S. dollars, the Space Station would be
the most expensive object ever built. The whole world watched as a Russian rocket launched 
the first module of the ISS into the sky. Zarya, meaning sunrise, 
was equipped with two solar panels and a propulsion system 
that had the important task of keeping the young station 
from crashing into the Earth by staying a safe 400 kilometers away. The U.S. Space Shuttle Endeavour
followed two weeks later carrying Unity, a node module to which
other modules could be connected, and an international 
six-person assembly crew. Then came Zvezda, which brought
communications and living accommodations. Ever since the International 
Space Station's first tenants arrived, it's been continually occupied with more than 200 visitors spending 
an average of six months on board. Astronaut Samantha Cristoforetti 
holds the record for the longest single space flight
by a woman at 199 days on the ISS. 2001 saw the arrival of Destiny,
the first of four research modules, where astronauts spend
approximately 36 hours a week conducting extraordinary experiments
in microgravity. Their schedules are packed with exercise, two hours a day to fend off 
muscle atrophy, station maintenance and repair, and connecting with family 
or awe-inspired minds around the world. But they still find time for fun,
with regular movie nights and even shooting 
the first music video in space. Destiny also controls the seven-jointed
robotic Canadarm2. Capable of moving 
more than 100,000 kilograms, it's perfect for unloading 
new arrivals from shuttles. 2001 was a busy year for the Space Station
with the addition of Quest, the main airlock for strolls outside, and Pirs, a pier for Russian 
spacecrafts to dock including the ever-ready 
emergency escape vehicle, Soyuz. Then, on February 1st, 2003, after delivering 
research modules to the ISS, the space shuttle
Columbia exploded during reentry tragically killing 
the seven-member crew on board. After a four-year hiatus, work quickly
picked up pace with the addition of more hubs, 
airlocks, docks, and an observation cupola for stunning
360-degree views of our world and beyond. Other critical components included 
platforms and trusses to support radiators that direct all the heat generated
by the station's electronics into space and solar panels that are efficient enough
to power 55 homes. It took ten years and over 30 missions, but finally, the International 
Space Station was complete, coinciding with the U.S. Space 
Shuttle Program's retirement. The Space Station continues to serve
as an incredible model for international collaboration. This year, two people 
began a one-year stay on the ISS, allowing scientists to study the long-term
physical and psychological effects of being in space, which would prove useful for increasingly
ambitious space travel, like trips to Mars. Over its lifetime, we've learned 
an immense amount scientifically, but also about 
our capacity to work together and accomplish truly remarkable acts.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
An estimated 20 million cases of blindness
worldwide are caused by cataracts, a curable condition affecting the lens
that focuses images onto the eye's retina. A cataract occurs when proteins 
in the lens lose their normal arrangement, clumping together in a way that causes
discoloration or clouding, and eventually blocks most vision. Cataracts can be caused by eye injury, certain medications, ultraviolet radiation, diabetes, smoking, or some genetic disorders. But the most common cause is aging. In the United States, more than 50%
of people over the age of 80 develop them. Cataracts were treated 
over 2,500 years ago in India, though similar procedures 
may have existed even earlier in Ancient Egypt and Babylon. The most common procedure,
called couching, involved pressing 
a sharp instrument into the eye to loosen and push 
the clouded lens out of the way. Although this could increase 
the amount of light entering the eye, the lack of a lens would leave 
the patient's vision out of focus. Despite its low success rate,
and high risk of infection or injury, couching is still performed 
in some parts of the world. Later procedures would also focus
on removing the cloudy lens, for example, by making an opening
in the cornea to pull out the lens along with the membrane capsule 
surrounding it. While the invention of eyeglasses
allowed for some restoration of focus, they had to be extremely thick to help. Furthermore, such techniques
still caused complications, like damaging the retina, or leaving the eye 
with uncomfortable stitches. But in the 20th century, 
something unexpected happened. Eye surgeon Sir Harold Ridley was treating
World War II casualties when he noticed that acrylic plastic from
a shattered aircraft cockpit had become lodged in a pilot's eyes
without triggering an adverse reaction. This led him to propose surgically
implanting artificial lenses into the eye to replace cataracts. And despite initial resistance, the method became standard practice
by the 1980s. Since Ridley's discovery, the intraocular lens 
has undergone several improvements. Modern lenses can fit 
into the membrane capsule that the cataract is extracted from, leaving more of 
the eye's natural anatomy intact. And the ability to fine-tune 
the lens curvature allows the surgery to restore 
a patient's normal vision without the need for glasses. Of course, surgical techniques 
have also progressed. Microscopic procedures use 
small instruments or lasers to make precise incisions of one 
or two millimeters in the cornea, while an ultrasound probe breaks up
and removes the cataracted lens with minimal trauma to the eye. Low-tech versions of this operation have
made the surgery quick and inexpensive, helping it spread 
across the developing world. Places like Aravind Eye Hospital in India have pioneered high-volume, 
low-cost cataract surgery for as little as six dollars. Why then, with all these advances, are there still so many 
blind people in the world? The main issue is access to health care, with poor infrastructure 
and a shortage of doctors being a major barrier in many regions. But this is not the only problem. In many rural areas with poor education, blindness is often accepted 
as an inevitable part of aging, for which someone 
might not think to seek treatment. This is why information is crucial. Increased community awareness programs
and the spread of mobile phones mean that many of those who might have remained blind for
the rest of their lives due to cataracts are now reachable. And for them, 
a brighter future is in sight.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many people in the world are estimated to be blind from cataracts?
Options: A. 20,000, B. 80,000, C. 20,000,000, D. 39,000,000
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated number of cases of blindness worldwide caused by cataracts? Options: A. 10 million, B. 20 million, C. 30 million, D. 40 million Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the most common cause of cataracts, accounting for more than 50% of cases in people over 80 in the United States? Options: A. Eye injury, B. Certain medications, C. Ultraviolet radiation, D. Aging Correct Option: D
Question 3: What was the name of the ancient procedure used to treat cataracts in India, which involved pressing a sharp instrument into the eye to loosen and push the clouded lens out of the way? Options: A. Couching, B. Laser surgery, C. Intraocular lens implantation, D. Corneal transplantation Correct Option: A
Question 4: What was the major breakthrough in cataract surgery discovered by Sir Harold Ridley, inspired by his observation of acrylic plastic in a pilot's eye during World War II? Options: A. The use of eyeglasses to restore focus, B. The removal of the cloudy lens through an opening in the cornea, C. The surgical implantation of artificial lenses into the eye, D. The use of ultrasound to break up and remove the cataracted lens Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the main issue preventing people with cataracts from receiving treatment, particularly in developing countries? Options: A. Lack of access to healthcare, B. High cost of surgery, C. Limited availability of artificial lenses, D. Poor education about cataract treatment Correct Option: A
Question 6: How has the intraocular lens undergone improvements since its discovery? Options: A. It has become more expensive, B. It has been replaced by laser surgery, C. It can now fit into the membrane capsule, leaving more of the eye's natural anatomy intact, D. It is no longer used in cataract surgery Correct Option: C
Question 7: What has made cataract surgery more accessible to people in developing countries, with some hospitals offering the procedure for as little as six dollars? Options: A. The use of advanced technology, B. The development of low-tech versions of the operation, C. The increase in the number of doctors, D. The decrease in the cost of artificial lenses Correct Option: B
Question 8: Why do some people in rural areas not seek treatment for cataracts, despite the availability of effective treatment options? Options: A. They are not aware of the treatment options, B. They cannot afford the surgery, C. They believe blindness is an inevitable part of aging, D. They do not have access to healthcare Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to ask about the estimated number of cases of blindness worldwide caused by cataracts. The options in Question 1 are also similar to those in the ground truth MCQ, with the correct option being 20 million.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
An estimated 20 million cases of blindness
worldwide are caused by cataracts, a curable condition affecting the lens
that focuses images onto the eye's retina. A cataract occurs when proteins 
in the lens lose their normal arrangement, clumping together in a way that causes
discoloration or clouding, and eventually blocks most vision. Cataracts can be caused by eye injury, certain medications, ultraviolet radiation, diabetes, smoking, or some genetic disorders. But the most common cause is aging. In the United States, more than 50%
of people over the age of 80 develop them. Cataracts were treated 
over 2,500 years ago in India, though similar procedures 
may have existed even earlier in Ancient Egypt and Babylon. The most common procedure,
called couching, involved pressing 
a sharp instrument into the eye to loosen and push 
the clouded lens out of the way. Although this could increase 
the amount of light entering the eye, the lack of a lens would leave 
the patient's vision out of focus. Despite its low success rate,
and high risk of infection or injury, couching is still performed 
in some parts of the world. Later procedures would also focus
on removing the cloudy lens, for example, by making an opening
in the cornea to pull out the lens along with the membrane capsule 
surrounding it. While the invention of eyeglasses
allowed for some restoration of focus, they had to be extremely thick to help. Furthermore, such techniques
still caused complications, like damaging the retina, or leaving the eye 
with uncomfortable stitches. But in the 20th century, 
something unexpected happened. Eye surgeon Sir Harold Ridley was treating
World War II casualties when he noticed that acrylic plastic from
a shattered aircraft cockpit had become lodged in a pilot's eyes
without triggering an adverse reaction. This led him to propose surgically
implanting artificial lenses into the eye to replace cataracts. And despite initial resistance, the method became standard practice
by the 1980s. Since Ridley's discovery, the intraocular lens 
has undergone several improvements. Modern lenses can fit 
into the membrane capsule that the cataract is extracted from, leaving more of 
the eye's natural anatomy intact. And the ability to fine-tune 
the lens curvature allows the surgery to restore 
a patient's normal vision without the need for glasses. Of course, surgical techniques 
have also progressed. Microscopic procedures use 
small instruments or lasers to make precise incisions of one 
or two millimeters in the cornea, while an ultrasound probe breaks up
and removes the cataracted lens with minimal trauma to the eye. Low-tech versions of this operation have
made the surgery quick and inexpensive, helping it spread 
across the developing world. Places like Aravind Eye Hospital in India have pioneered high-volume, 
low-cost cataract surgery for as little as six dollars. Why then, with all these advances, are there still so many 
blind people in the world? The main issue is access to health care, with poor infrastructure 
and a shortage of doctors being a major barrier in many regions. But this is not the only problem. In many rural areas with poor education, blindness is often accepted 
as an inevitable part of aging, for which someone 
might not think to seek treatment. This is why information is crucial. Increased community awareness programs
and the spread of mobile phones mean that many of those who might have remained blind for
the rest of their lives due to cataracts are now reachable. And for them, 
a brighter future is in sight.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What proportion of people worldwide is blind from causes termed "avoidable"
Options: A. 15%, B. 33%, C. 50%, D. 80%
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated number of cases of blindness worldwide caused by cataracts? Options: A. 10 million, B. 20 million, C. 30 million, D. 40 million Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the most common cause of cataracts, accounting for more than 50% of cases in people over 80 in the United States? Options: A. Eye injury, B. Certain medications, C. Ultraviolet radiation, D. Aging Correct Option: D
Question 3: What was the name of the ancient procedure used to treat cataracts in India, which involved pressing a sharp instrument into the eye to loosen and push the clouded lens out of the way? Options: A. Couching, B. Laser surgery, C. Intraocular lens implantation, D. Corneal transplantation Correct Option: A
Question 4: What was the major breakthrough in cataract surgery discovered by Sir Harold Ridley, inspired by his observation of acrylic plastic in a pilot's eye during World War II? Options: A. The use of eyeglasses to restore focus, B. The removal of the cloudy lens through an opening in the cornea, C. The surgical implantation of artificial lenses into the eye, D. The use of ultrasound to break up and remove the cataracted lens Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the main issue preventing people with cataracts from receiving treatment, particularly in developing countries? Options: A. Lack of access to healthcare, B. High cost of surgery, C. Limited availability of artificial lenses, D. Poor education about cataract treatment Correct Option: A
Question 6: How has the intraocular lens undergone improvements since its discovery? Options: A. It has become more expensive, B. It has been replaced by laser surgery, C. It can now fit into the membrane capsule, leaving more of the eye's natural anatomy intact, D. It is no longer used in cataract surgery Correct Option: C
Question 7: What has made cataract surgery more accessible to people in developing countries, with some hospitals offering the procedure for as little as six dollars? Options: A. The use of advanced technology, B. The development of low-tech versions of the operation, C. The increase in the number of doctors, D. The decrease in the cost of artificial lenses Correct Option: B
Question 8: Why do some people in rural areas not seek treatment for cataracts, despite the availability of effective treatment options? Options: A. They are not aware of the treatment options, B. They cannot afford the surgery, C. They believe blindness is an inevitable part of aging, D. They do not have access to healthcare Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, I can identify a generated MCQ that shares a similar intent and topic.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the proportion of people worldwide who are blind from "avoidable" causes, while the generated MCQs focus on cataracts as a specific cause of blindness. Among the generated MCQs, Question 1 is the most relevant, as it asks about the estimated number of cases of blindness worldwide caused by cataracts.

Although the question content and options do not exactly match, I would argue that Question 1 is the most similar generated MCQ, as it addresses the topic of blindness caused by cataracts and provides a quantitative estimate.

**Transcript**:
An estimated 20 million cases of blindness
worldwide are caused by cataracts, a curable condition affecting the lens
that focuses images onto the eye's retina. A cataract occurs when proteins 
in the lens lose their normal arrangement, clumping together in a way that causes
discoloration or clouding, and eventually blocks most vision. Cataracts can be caused by eye injury, certain medications, ultraviolet radiation, diabetes, smoking, or some genetic disorders. But the most common cause is aging. In the United States, more than 50%
of people over the age of 80 develop them. Cataracts were treated 
over 2,500 years ago in India, though similar procedures 
may have existed even earlier in Ancient Egypt and Babylon. The most common procedure,
called couching, involved pressing 
a sharp instrument into the eye to loosen and push 
the clouded lens out of the way. Although this could increase 
the amount of light entering the eye, the lack of a lens would leave 
the patient's vision out of focus. Despite its low success rate,
and high risk of infection or injury, couching is still performed 
in some parts of the world. Later procedures would also focus
on removing the cloudy lens, for example, by making an opening
in the cornea to pull out the lens along with the membrane capsule 
surrounding it. While the invention of eyeglasses
allowed for some restoration of focus, they had to be extremely thick to help. Furthermore, such techniques
still caused complications, like damaging the retina, or leaving the eye 
with uncomfortable stitches. But in the 20th century, 
something unexpected happened. Eye surgeon Sir Harold Ridley was treating
World War II casualties when he noticed that acrylic plastic from
a shattered aircraft cockpit had become lodged in a pilot's eyes
without triggering an adverse reaction. This led him to propose surgically
implanting artificial lenses into the eye to replace cataracts. And despite initial resistance, the method became standard practice
by the 1980s. Since Ridley's discovery, the intraocular lens 
has undergone several improvements. Modern lenses can fit 
into the membrane capsule that the cataract is extracted from, leaving more of 
the eye's natural anatomy intact. And the ability to fine-tune 
the lens curvature allows the surgery to restore 
a patient's normal vision without the need for glasses. Of course, surgical techniques 
have also progressed. Microscopic procedures use 
small instruments or lasers to make precise incisions of one 
or two millimeters in the cornea, while an ultrasound probe breaks up
and removes the cataracted lens with minimal trauma to the eye. Low-tech versions of this operation have
made the surgery quick and inexpensive, helping it spread 
across the developing world. Places like Aravind Eye Hospital in India have pioneered high-volume,

as an inevitable part of aging, for which someone

a brighter future is in sight.

An estimated 20 million cases of blindness
worldwide are caused by cataracts, a curable condition affecting the lens
that focuses images onto the eye's retina. A cataract occurs when proteins 
in the lens lose their normal arrangement, clumping together in a way that causes

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Think back to a really vivid memory. Got it? Okay, now try to remember what 
you had for lunch three weeks ago. That second memory 
probably isn't as strong, but why not? Why do we remember some things,
and not others? And why do memories eventually fade? Let's look at how memories form
in the first place. When you experience something,
like dialing a phone number, the experience is converted 
into a pulse of electrical energy that zips along a network of neurons. Information first lands 
in short term memory, where it's available 
from anywhere from a few seconds to a couple of minutes. It's then transferred to long-term memory
through areas such as the hippocampus, and finally to several storage regions
across the brain. Neurons throughout the brain
communicate at dedicated sites called synapses using specialized neurotransmitters. If two neurons communicate repeatedly,
a remarkable thing happens: the efficiency of communication 
between them increases. This process, 
called long term potentiation, is considered to be a mechanism
by which memories are stored long-term, but how do some memories get lost? Age is one factor. As we get older, 
synapses begin to falter and weaken, affecting how easily 
we can retrieve memories. Scientists have several theories about
what's behind this deterioration, from actual brain shrinkage, the hippocampus 
loses 5% of its neurons every decade for a total loss of 20% by the time 
you're 80 years old to the drop in the production 
of neurotransmitters, like acetylcholine,
which is vital to learning and memory. These changes seem to affect how people
retrieve stored information. Age also affects 
our memory-making abilities. Memories are encoded most strongly
when we're paying attention, when we're deeply engaged,
and when information is meaningful to us. Mental and physical health problems,
which tend to increase as we age, interfere with our ability 
to pay attention, and thus act as memory thieves. Another leading cause of memory problems
is chronic stress. When we're constantly overloaded with work
and personal responsibilites, our bodies are on hyperalert. This response has evolved from
the physiological mechanism designed to make sure 
we can survive in a crisis. Stress chemicals help mobilize energy
and increase alertness. However, with chronic stress our bodies
become flooded with these chemicals, resulting in a loss of brain cells
and an inability to form new ones, which affects our ability 
to retain new information. Depression is another culprit. People who are depressed are 40%
more likely to develop memory problems. Low levels of serotonin, a neurotransmitter connected to arousal, may make depressed individuals 
less attentive to new information. Dwelling on sad events in the past,
another symptom of depression, makes it difficult to pay 
attention to the present, affecting the ability to store
short-term memories. Isolation, which is tied to depression,
is another memory thief. A study by the Harvard School 
of Public Health found that older people 
with high levels of social integration had a slower rate of memory decline
over a six-year period. The exact reason remains unclear, but experts suspect that social interaction 
gives our brain a mental workout. Just like muscle strength, we have to use our brain
or risk losing it. But don't despair. There are several steps you can take to aid your brain 
in preserving your memories. Make sure you keep physically active. Increased blood flow 
to the brain is helpful. And eat well. Your brain needs all the right nutrients
to keep functioning correctly. And finally, give your brain a workout. Exposing your brain to challenges,
like learning a new language, is one of the best defenses for keeping
your memories intact.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Long term potentiation is a mechanism by which:
Options: A. Memories are lost, B. Memories are stored, C. Memories are formed
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary mechanism by which neurons communicate at synapses? Options: A. Electrical energy, B. Neurotransmitters, C. Hormones, D. Glial cells Correct Option: B
Question 2: What percentage of neurons does the hippocampus lose every decade? Options: A. 2%, B. 5%, C. 10%, D. 15% Correct Option: B
Question 3: How does age affect memory-making abilities? Options: A. Improves memory retrieval and formation, B. Has no significant impact on memory, C. Declines memory retrieval and formation, D. Increases the risk of memory-related diseases Correct Option: C
Question 4: What lifestyle choices can help preserve memories, according to research? Options: A. Social isolation and a sedentary lifestyle, B. Physical activity, a healthy diet, and mental stimulation, C. Chronic stress and depression management, D. Cognitive training programs only Correct Option: B
Question 5: How can individuals mitigate the negative effects of chronic stress on memory? Options: A. Engage in more stressful activities to build resilience, B. Manage chronic stress through relaxation techniques and lifestyle changes, C. Ignore the impact of chronic stress on memory, D. Focus solely on physical activity and diet Correct Option: B
Question 6: What lifestyle choices can older adults make to support their brain health? Options: A. Physical activity and social isolation, B. Physical activity, a healthy diet, and mental stimulation, C. Cognitive training programs only, D. Ignoring the impact of age on memory Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the relationship between chronic stress and depression in terms of their impact on memory decline? Options: A. They have a neutral effect on memory decline, B. They have a compounding effect on memory decline, C. They have a negligible impact on memory decline, D. They only affect memory decline separately Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is a crucial factor for preserving memories, according to research? Options: A. Neuroplasticity, B. Cognitive training programs, C. Physical activity and diet, D. Social interaction Correct Option: D
Question 9: What can be created by combining knowledge of memory formation with an understanding of age-related decline? Options: A. A comprehensive approach to supporting physical health, B. A targeted intervention for improving memory, C. A new cognitive training program, D. A holistic approach to supporting mental health Correct Option: B
Question 10: What can be developed by recognizing the interconnections between chronic stress, depression, and memory decline? Options: A. More effective strategies for mitigating these effects, B. New cognitive training programs, C. A comprehensive approach to supporting physical health, D. A holistic approach to supporting mental health Correct Option: A
Question 11: What should be considered when evaluating the effectiveness of different strategies for improving memory? Options: A. Only the cost of the strategies, B. Only the short-term benefits of the strategies, C. The long-term benefits, limitations, and potential risks of the strategies, D. Only the opinions of experts in the field Correct Option: C
Question 12: What should be taken into account when justifying the importance of social interaction and mental stimulation for preserving memories? Options: A. Only the physical health benefits, B. Only the mental health benefits, C. The complex relationships between physical and mental health, D. Only the opinions of experts in the field Correct Option: C
Question 13: What happens to the efficiency of communication between neurons when they communicate repeatedly? Options: A. It decreases, B. It remains the same, C. It increases, D. It becomes unpredictable Correct Option: C
Question 14: What is the primary effect of depression on memory? Options: A. Improved memory retrieval and formation, B. No significant impact on memory, C. Decline in memory retrieval and formation, D. Increased risk of memory-related diseases Correct Option: C
Question 15: What is the name of the process by which memories are stored long-term? Options: A. Long-term potentiation, B. Neuroplasticity, C. Synaptic pruning, D. Neurogenesis Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 15: What is the name of the process by which memories are stored long-term? Options: A. Long-term potentiation, B. Neuroplasticity, C. Synaptic pruning, D. Neurogenesis Correct Option: A**

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the mechanism by which memories are stored long-term, and both have long-term potentiation as the correct answer.

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: **15**

like learning a new language, is one of the best defenses for keeping
your memories intact.

Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Think back to a really vivid memory. Got it? Okay, now try to remember what 
you had for lunch three weeks ago. That second memory 
probably isn't as strong, but why not? Why do we remember some things,
and not others? And why do memories eventually fade? Let's look at how memories form
in the first place. When you experience something,
like dialing a phone number, the experience is converted 
into a pulse of electrical energy that zips along a network of neurons. Information first lands 
in short term memory, where it's available 
from anywhere from a few seconds to a couple of minutes. It's then transferred to long-term memory
through areas such as the hippocampus, and finally to several storage regions
across the brain. Neurons throughout the brain
communicate at dedicated sites called synapses using specialized neurotransmitters. If two neurons communicate repeatedly,
a remarkable thing happens: the efficiency of communication 
between them increases. This process, 
called long term potentiation, is considered to be a mechanism
by which memories are stored long-term, but how do some memories get lost? Age is one factor. As we get older, 
synapses begin to falter and weaken, affecting how easily 
we can retrieve memories. Scientists have several theories about
what's behind this deterioration, from actual brain shrinkage, the hippocampus 
loses 5% of its neurons every decade for a total loss of 20% by the time 
you're 80 years old to the drop in the production 
of neurotransmitters, like acetylcholine,
which is vital to learning and memory. These changes seem to affect how people
retrieve stored information. Age also affects 
our memory-making abilities. Memories are encoded most strongly
when we're paying attention, when we're deeply engaged,
and when information is meaningful to us. Mental and physical health problems,
which tend to increase as we age, interfere with our ability 
to pay attention, and thus act as memory thieves. Another leading cause of memory problems
is chronic stress. When we're constantly overloaded with work
and personal responsibilites, our bodies are on hyperalert. This response has evolved from
the physiological mechanism designed to make sure 
we can survive in a crisis. Stress chemicals help mobilize energy
and increase alertness. However, with chronic stress our bodies
become flooded with these chemicals, resulting in a loss of brain cells
and an inability to form new ones, which affects our ability 
to retain new information. Depression is another culprit. People who are depressed are 40%
more likely to develop memory problems. Low levels of serotonin, a neurotransmitter connected to arousal, may make depressed individuals 
less attentive to new information. Dwelling on sad events in the past,
another symptom of depression, makes it difficult to pay 
attention to the present, affecting the ability to store
short-term memories. Isolation, which is tied to depression,
is another memory thief. A study by the Harvard School 
of Public Health found that older people 
with high levels of social integration had a slower rate of memory decline
over a six-year period. The exact reason remains unclear, but experts suspect that social interaction 
gives our brain a mental workout. Just like muscle strength, we have to use our brain
or risk losing it. But don't despair. There are several steps you can take to aid your brain 
in preserving your memories. Make sure you keep physically active. Increased blood flow 
to the brain is helpful. And eat well. Your brain needs all the right nutrients
to keep functioning correctly. And finally, give your brain a workout. Exposing your brain to challenges,
like learning a new language, is one of the best defenses for keeping
your memories intact.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The major factor that promotes our ability to retrieve information from long-term memory is:
Options: A. Stress, B. Boredom, C. Paying attention to meaningful information, D. Depression
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary mechanism by which neurons communicate at synapses? Options: A. Electrical energy, B. Neurotransmitters, C. Hormones, D. Glial cells Correct Option: B
Question 2: What percentage of neurons does the hippocampus lose every decade? Options: A. 2%, B. 5%, C. 10%, D. 15% Correct Option: B
Question 3: How does age affect memory-making abilities? Options: A. Improves memory retrieval and formation, B. Has no significant impact on memory, C. Declines memory retrieval and formation, D. Increases the risk of memory-related diseases Correct Option: C
Question 4: What lifestyle choices can help preserve memories, according to research? Options: A. Social isolation and a sedentary lifestyle, B. Physical activity, a healthy diet, and mental stimulation, C. Chronic stress and depression management, D. Cognitive training programs only Correct Option: B
Question 5: How can individuals mitigate the negative effects of chronic stress on memory? Options: A. Engage in more stressful activities to build resilience, B. Manage chronic stress through relaxation techniques and lifestyle changes, C. Ignore the impact of chronic stress on memory, D. Focus solely on physical activity and diet Correct Option: B
Question 6: What lifestyle choices can older adults make to support their brain health? Options: A. Physical activity and social isolation, B. Physical activity, a healthy diet, and mental stimulation, C. Cognitive training programs only, D. Ignoring the impact of age on memory Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the relationship between chronic stress and depression in terms of their impact on memory decline? Options: A. They have a neutral effect on memory decline, B. They have a compounding effect on memory decline, C. They have a negligible impact on memory decline, D. They only affect memory decline separately Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is a crucial factor for preserving memories, according to research? Options: A. Neuroplasticity, B. Cognitive training programs, C. Physical activity and diet, D. Social interaction Correct Option: D
Question 9: What can be created by combining knowledge of memory formation with an understanding of age-related decline? Options: A. A comprehensive approach to supporting physical health, B. A targeted intervention for improving memory, C. A new cognitive training program, D. A holistic approach to supporting mental health Correct Option: B
Question 10: What can be developed by recognizing the interconnections between chronic stress, depression, and memory decline? Options: A. More effective strategies for mitigating these effects, B. New cognitive training programs, C. A comprehensive approach to supporting physical health, D. A holistic approach to supporting mental health Correct Option: A
Question 11: What should be considered when evaluating the effectiveness of different strategies for improving memory? Options: A. Only the cost of the strategies, B. Only the short-term benefits of the strategies, C. The long-term benefits, limitations, and potential risks of the strategies, D. Only the opinions of experts in the field Correct Option: C
Question 12: What should be taken into account when justifying the importance of social interaction and mental stimulation for preserving memories? Options: A. Only the physical health benefits, B. Only the mental health benefits, C. The complex relationships between physical and mental health, D. Only the opinions of experts in the field Correct Option: C
Question 13: What happens to the efficiency of communication between neurons when they communicate repeatedly? Options: A. It decreases, B. It remains the same, C. It increases, D. It becomes unpredictable Correct Option: C
Question 14: What is the primary effect of depression on memory? Options: A. Improved memory retrieval and formation, B. No significant impact on memory, C. Decline in memory retrieval and formation, D. Increased risk of memory-related diseases Correct Option: C
Question 15: What is the name of the process by which memories are stored long-term? Options: A. Long-term potentiation, B. Neuroplasticity, C. Synaptic pruning, D. Neurogenesis Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Think back to a really vivid memory. Got it? Okay, now try to remember what 
you had for lunch three weeks ago. That second memory 
probably isn't as strong, but why not? Why do we remember some things,
and not others? And why do memories eventually fade? Let's look at how memories form
in the first place. When you experience something,
like dialing a phone number, the experience is converted 
into a pulse of electrical energy that zips along a network of neurons. Information first lands 
in short term memory, where it's available 
from anywhere from a few seconds to a couple of minutes. It's then transferred to long-term memory
through areas such as the hippocampus, and finally to several storage regions
across the brain. Neurons throughout the brain
communicate at dedicated sites called synapses using specialized neurotransmitters. If two neurons communicate repeatedly,
a remarkable thing happens: the efficiency of communication 
between them increases. This process, 
called long term potentiation, is considered to be a mechanism
by which memories are stored long-term, but how do some memories get lost? Age is one factor. As we get older, 
synapses begin to falter and weaken, affecting how easily 
we can retrieve memories. Scientists have several theories about
what's behind this deterioration, from actual brain shrinkage, the hippocampus 
loses 5% of its neurons every decade for a total loss of 20% by the time 
you're 80 years old to the drop in the production 
of neurotransmitters, like acetylcholine,
which is vital to learning and memory. These changes seem to affect how people
retrieve stored information. Age also affects 
our memory-making abilities. Memories are encoded most strongly
when we're paying attention, when we're deeply engaged,
and when information is meaningful to us. Mental and physical health problems,
which tend to increase as we age, interfere with our ability 
to pay attention, and thus act as memory thieves. Another leading cause of memory problems
is chronic stress. When we're constantly overloaded with work
and personal responsibilites, our bodies are on hyperalert. This response has evolved from
the physiological mechanism designed to make sure 
we can survive in a crisis. Stress chemicals help mobilize energy
and increase alertness. However, with chronic stress our bodies
become flooded with these chemicals, resulting in a loss of brain cells
and an inability to form new ones, which affects our ability 
to retain new information. Depression is another culprit. People who are depressed are 40%
more likely to develop memory problems. Low levels of serotonin, a neurotransmitter connected to arousal, may make depressed individuals 
less attentive to new information. Dwelling on sad events in the past,
another symptom of depression, makes it difficult to pay 
attention to the present, affecting the ability to store
short-term memories. Isolation, which is tied to depression,
is another memory thief. A study by the Harvard School 
of Public Health found that older people 
with high levels of social integration had a slower rate of memory decline
over a six-year period. The exact reason remains unclear, but experts suspect that social interaction 
gives our brain a mental workout. Just like muscle strength, we have to use our brain
or risk losing it. But don't despair. There are several steps you can take to aid your brain 
in preserving your memories. Make sure you keep physically active. Increased blood flow 
to the brain is helpful. And eat well. Your brain needs all the right nutrients
to keep functioning correctly. And finally, give your brain a workout. Exposing your brain to challenges,
like learning a new language, is one of the best defenses for keeping
your memories intact.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: We can do the following to preserve our memories EXCEPT:
Options: A. Exercise, B. Eat healthily, C. Take drugs, D. Participate in mentally stimulating activities
Correct Option: C

Question 1: What is the primary mechanism by which neurons communicate at synapses? Options: A. Electrical energy, B. Neurotransmitters, C. Hormones, D. Glial cells Correct Option: B

Question 3: How does age affect memory-making abilities? Options: A. Improves memory retrieval and formation, B. Has no significant impact on memory, C. Declines memory retrieval and formation, D. Increases the risk of memory-related diseases Correct Option: C

Physical activity, a healthy diet, and mental stimulation, C. Chronic stress and depression management, D. Cognitive training programs only Correct Option: B

Question 7: What is the relationship between chronic stress and depression in terms of their impact on memory decline? Options: A. They have a neutral effect on memory decline, B. They have a compounding effect on memory decline, C. They have a negligible impact on memory decline, D. They only affect memory decline separately Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is a crucial factor for preserving memories, according to research? Options: A. Neuroplasticity, B. Cognitive training programs, C. Physical activity and diet, D. Social interaction Correct Option: D

A targeted intervention for improving memory, C. A new cognitive training program, D. A holistic approach to supporting mental health Correct Option: B
Question 10: What can be developed by recognizing the interconnections between chronic stress, depression, and memory decline? Options: A. More effective strategies for mitigating these effects, B. New cognitive training programs, C. A comprehensive approach to supporting physical health, D. A holistic approach to supporting mental health Correct Option: A
Question 11: What should be considered when evaluating the effectiveness of different strategies for improving memory? Options: A. Only the cost of the strategies, B. Only the short-term benefits of the strategies, C. The long-term benefits, limitations, and potential risks of the strategies, D. Only the opinions of experts in the field Correct Option: C
Question 12: What should be taken into account when justifying the importance of social interaction and mental stimulation for preserving memories? Options: A. Only the physical health benefits, B. Only the mental health benefits, C. The complex relationships between physical and mental health, D. Only the opinions of experts in the field Correct Option: C
Question 13: What happens to the efficiency of communication between neurons when they communicate repeatedly? Options: A. It decreases, B. It remains the same, C. It increases, D. It becomes unpredictable Correct Option: C
Question 14: What is the primary effect of depression on memory? Options: A. Improved memory retrieval and formation, B. No significant impact on memory, C. Decline in memory retrieval and formation, D. Increased risk of memory-related diseases Correct Option: C
Question 15: What is the name of the process by which memories are stored long-term? Options: A. Long-term potentiation, B. Neuroplasticity, C. Synaptic pruning, D. Neurogenesis Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
people who have a growth mindset believe that intelligence can be developed while people with a fixed mindset believe that intelligence is a fixed trait people with a fixed mindset think of intelligence kind of like eye color they believe that you're born with a certain amount of intelligence and you can't do much to change that people with the growth mindset think of intelligence more like a muscle they understand that when you put in effort and challenge yourself you can get smarter just just like when you put an effort at the gym and challenge Yourself by lifting heavier weights to make your muscle stronger think about this statement you can learn new things but you can't really change your basic intelligence people who really agree with this statement have a fixed mindset people who really disagree with this statement have a growth mindset and of course people might be somewhere in the middle it turns out that the more students disagree with statements like these the more they have a growth mindset the better they do in school this is because students with a growth mindset approach School differently than students with the fixed mindset they have different goals in school the main goal for students with a fixed mindset is to show how smart they are or to hide how unintelligent they are this makes sense if you think that intelligence is something you either have or you don't have you want to show that you have it students with a fixed mindset will avoid asking questions when they don't understand something because they want to preserve the image that they are smart or hide that they're not smart but the main goal for students with the growth mindset is to learn this also makes a lot of sense if you think that intelligence is something you can develop the way you develop your intelligence is by learning new things so students with the growth mindset will ask questions when they don't understand something because that's how they'll learn similarly students with a fixed mindset view effort negatively they think if I have to try I must not be very smart at this while students with a growth mindset view effort as the way that you learn the way that you get smarter where you'll really see a difference in students with fixed and growth mindsets is when they are faced with a challenge or setback students with a fixed mindset will give up because they think their setback means they're not smart but students with a growth mindset actually like challenges if they already knew how to do something it wouldn't be an opportunity to learn to develop their intelligence given that students with a growth mindset try harder in school especially in the face of a challenge it's no surprise they do better in school

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which type of student believes that intelligence is a fixed trait?
Options: A. A student with a growth mindset, B. A student with a fixed mindset
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What do people with a growth mindset believe about intelligence? Options: A. It is a fixed trait that cannot be changed., B. It is a muscle that can be developed through effort and learning., C. It is determined by genetics and environment., D. It is only developed through formal education. Correct Option: B
Question 2: How do students with a growth mindset view effort compared to students with a fixed mindset? Options: A. Students with a growth mindset view effort negatively, while students with a fixed mindset view effort positively., B. Students with a growth mindset view effort positively, while students with a fixed mindset view effort negatively., C. Students with a growth mindset view effort as unnecessary, while students with a fixed mindset view effort as essential., D. Students with a growth mindset view effort as only necessary for difficult tasks. Correct Option: B
Question 3: How do students with a growth mindset approach challenges compared to students with a fixed mindset? Options: A. Students with a growth mindset give up easily, while students with a fixed mindset persist., B. Students with a growth mindset persist and view challenges as opportunities for growth., C. Students with a growth mindset avoid challenges, while students with a fixed mindset seek out challenges., D. Students with a growth mindset seek out challenges, but only if they are easy to overcome. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the primary goal of students with a growth mindset compared to students with a fixed mindset? Options: A. Students with a growth mindset aim to show how smart they are, while students with a fixed mindset aim to learn., B. Students with a growth mindset aim to learn and develop their intelligence., C. Students with a growth mindset aim to avoid failure, while students with a fixed mindset aim to achieve success., D. Students with a growth mindset aim to achieve success, but only if it is easy to achieve. Correct Option: B
Question 5: A student is struggling with a difficult math problem. What would a student with a growth mindset likely do in this situation? Options: A. Give up and move on to a different problem., B. Ask questions and persist in trying to solve the problem., C. Avoid asking for help and try to solve the problem on their own., D. Look for an easier problem to solve instead. Correct Option: B
Question 6: How can teachers use the concept of growth and fixed mindsets to inform their teaching strategies? Options: A. By praising students' intelligence rather than their effort., B. By providing extra support only to students with a fixed mindset., C. By encouraging students to adopt a growth mindset and praising effort rather than just intelligence., D. By giving up on students who have a fixed mindset. Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the relationship between mindset and academic performance? Options: A. Students with a fixed mindset tend to do better in school., B. Students with a growth mindset tend to do better in school., C. There is no relationship between mindset and academic performance., D. Students with a growth mindset tend to do worse in school. Correct Option: B
Question 8: (Removed this question as it's similar to question 3) Options:  Correct Option: None
Question 9: What could be the result of combining the concept of growth and fixed mindsets with other educational theories, such as self-efficacy and self-regulated learning? Options: A. A more limited understanding of student motivation and achievement., B. A more comprehensive understanding of student motivation and achievement., C. A complete rejection of the concept of growth and fixed mindsets., D. No impact on our understanding of student motivation and achievement. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What could be the result of integrating growth mindset principles into educational policies and practices? Options: A. Improved academic outcomes and a more supportive learning environment., B. Decreased academic outcomes and a less supportive learning environment., C. No impact on academic outcomes or the learning environment., D. Only improved academic outcomes, but not a more supportive learning environment. Correct Option: A
Question 11: (Removed this question as it's similar to question 7) Options:  Correct Option: None
Question 12: Why is it important to promote a growth mindset in educational settings? Options: A. Because it has no impact on students' motivation, engagement, and achievement., B. Because it can lead to decreased motivation, engagement, and achievement., C. Because it can lead to improved motivation, engagement, and achievement., D. Because it is a popular educational theory. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1.

Question 1 asks about the growth mindset, whereas the ground truth MCQ asks about the fixed mindset. However, Question 1 provides the most relevant information related to the ground truth MCQ.

Question 2: How do students with a growth mindset view effort compared to students with a fixed mindset? Options: A. Students with a growth mindset view effort negatively, while students with a fixed mindset view effort positively., B. Students with a growth mindset view effort positively, while students with a fixed mindset view effort negatively., C. Students with a growth mindset view effort as unnecessary, while students with a fixed mindset view effort as essential., D. Students with a growth mindset view effort as only necessary for difficult tasks. Correct Option: B
Question 3: How do students with a growth mindset approach challenges compared to students with a fixed mindset? Options: A. Students with a growth mindset give up easily, while students with a fixed mindset persist., B. Students with a growth mindset persist and view challenges as opportunities for growth., C. Students with a growth mindset avoid challenges, while students with a fixed mindset seek out challenges., D. Students with a growth mindset seek out challenges, but only if they are easy to overcome. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the primary goal of students with a growth mindset compared to students with a fixed mindset? Options: A. Students with a growth mindset aim to show how smart they are, while students with a fixed mindset aim to learn., B. Students with a growth mindset aim to learn and develop their intelligence., C. Students with a growth mindset aim to avoid failure, while students with a fixed mindset aim to achieve success., D. Students with a growth mindset aim to achieve success, but only if it is easy to achieve. Correct Option: B
Question 5: A student is struggling with a difficult math problem. What would a student with a growth mindset likely do in this situation? Options: A. Give up and move on to a different problem., B. Ask questions and persist in trying to solve the problem., C. Avoid asking for help and try to solve the problem on their own., D. Look for an easier problem to solve instead. Correct Option: B
Question 6: How can teachers use the concept of growth and fixed mindsets to inform their teaching strategies? Options: A. By praising students' intelligence rather than their effort., B. By providing extra support only to students with a fixed mindset., C. By encouraging students to adopt a growth mindset and praising effort rather than just intelligence., D. By giving up on students who have a fixed mindset. Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the relationship between mindset and academic performance? Options: A. Students with a fixed mindset tend to do better in school., B. Students with a growth mindset tend to do better in school., C. There is no relationship between mindset and academic performance., D. Students with a growth mindset tend to do worse in school. Correct Option: B
Question 8: (Removed this question as it's similar to question 3) Options:  Correct Option: None
Question 9: What could be the result of combining the concept of growth and fixed mindsets with other educational theories, such as self-efficacy and self-regulated learning? Options: A. A more limited understanding of student motivation and achievement., B. A more comprehensive understanding of student motivation and achievement., C. A complete rejection of the concept of growth and fixed mindsets., D. No impact on our understanding of student motivation and achievement. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What could be the result of integrating growth mindset principles into educational policies and practices? Options: A. Improved academic outcomes and a more supportive learning environment., B. Decreased academic outcomes and a less supportive learning environment., C. No impact on academic outcomes or the learning environment., D. Only improved academic outcomes, but not a more supportive learning environment. Correct Option: A
Question 11: (Removed this question as it's similar to question 7) Options:  Correct Option: None
Question 12: Why is it important to promote a growth mindset in educational settings? Options: A. Because it has no impact on students' motivation, engagement, and achievement., B. Because it can lead to decreased motivation, engagement, and achievement., C. Because it can lead to improved motivation, engagement, and achievement., D. Because it is a popular educational theory. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1.

The correct option in both questions highlights the idea that people with a growth mindset believe that intelligence can be developed.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
people who have a growth mindset believe that intelligence can be developed while people with a fixed mindset believe that intelligence is a fixed trait people with a fixed mindset think of intelligence kind of like eye color they believe that you're born with a certain amount of intelligence and you can't do much to change that people with the growth mindset think of intelligence more like a muscle they understand that when you put in effort and challenge yourself you can get smarter just just like when you put an effort at the gym and challenge Yourself by lifting heavier weights to make your muscle stronger think about this statement you can learn new things but you can't really change your basic intelligence people who really agree with this statement have a fixed mindset people who really disagree with this statement have a growth mindset and of course people might be somewhere in the middle it turns out that the more students disagree with statements like these the more they have a growth mindset the better they do in school this is because students with a growth mindset approach School differently than students with the fixed mindset they have different goals in school the main goal for students with a fixed mindset is to show how smart they are or to hide how unintelligent they are this makes sense if you think that intelligence is something you either have or you don't have you want to show that you have it students with a fixed mindset will avoid asking questions when they don't understand something because they want to preserve the image that they are smart or hide that they're not smart but the main goal for students with the growth mindset is to learn this also makes a lot of sense if you think that intelligence is something you can develop the way you develop your intelligence is by learning new things so students with the growth mindset will ask questions when they don't understand something because that's how they'll learn similarly students with a fixed mindset view effort negatively they think if I have to try I must not be very smart at this while students with a growth mindset view effort as the way that you learn the way that you get smarter where you'll really see a difference in students with fixed and growth mindsets is when they are faced with a challenge or setback students with a fixed mindset will give up because they think their setback means they're not smart but students with a growth mindset actually like challenges if they already knew how to do something it wouldn't be an opportunity to learn to develop their intelligence given that students with a growth mindset try harder in school especially in the face of a challenge it's no surprise they do better in school

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which type of student would most likely say that intelligence is like a muscle; you have to put effort in and challenge yourself in order to help it grow?
Options: A. A student with a growth mindset, B. A student with a fixed mindset
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What do people with a growth mindset believe about intelligence? Options: A. It is a fixed trait that cannot be changed., B. It is a muscle that can be developed through effort and learning., C. It is determined by genetics and environment., D. It is only developed through formal education. Correct Option: B
Question 2: How do students with a growth mindset view effort compared to students with a fixed mindset? Options: A. Students with a growth mindset view effort negatively, while students with a fixed mindset view effort positively., B. Students with a growth mindset view effort positively, while students with a fixed mindset view effort negatively., C. Students with a growth mindset view effort as unnecessary, while students with a fixed mindset view effort as essential., D. Students with a growth mindset view effort as only necessary for difficult tasks. Correct Option: B
Question 3: How do students with a growth mindset approach challenges compared to students with a fixed mindset? Options: A. Students with a growth mindset give up easily, while students with a fixed mindset persist., B. Students with a growth mindset persist and view challenges as opportunities for growth., C. Students with a growth mindset avoid challenges, while students with a fixed mindset seek out challenges., D. Students with a growth mindset seek out challenges, but only if they are easy to overcome. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the primary goal of students with a growth mindset compared to students with a fixed mindset? Options: A. Students with a growth mindset aim to show how smart they are, while students with a fixed mindset aim to learn., B. Students with a growth mindset aim to learn and develop their intelligence., C. Students with a growth mindset aim to avoid failure, while students with a fixed mindset aim to achieve success., D. Students with a growth mindset aim to achieve success, but only if it is easy to achieve. Correct Option: B
Question 5: A student is struggling with a difficult math problem. What would a student with a growth mindset likely do in this situation? Options: A. Give up and move on to a different problem., B. Ask questions and persist in trying to solve the problem., C. Avoid asking for help and try to solve the problem on their own., D. Look for an easier problem to solve instead. Correct Option: B
Question 6: How can teachers use the concept of growth and fixed mindsets to inform their teaching strategies? Options: A. By praising students' intelligence rather than their effort., B. By providing extra support only to students with a fixed mindset., C. By encouraging students to adopt a growth mindset and praising effort rather than just intelligence., D. By giving up on students who have a fixed mindset. Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the relationship between mindset and academic performance? Options: A. Students with a fixed mindset tend to do better in school., B. Students with a growth mindset tend to do better in school., C. There is no relationship between mindset and academic performance., D. Students with a growth mindset tend to do worse in school. Correct Option: B

A more limited understanding of student motivation and achievement., B. A more comprehensive understanding of student motivation and achievement., C. A complete rejection of the concept of growth and fixed mindsets., D. No impact on our understanding of student motivation and achievement. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What could be the result of integrating growth mindset principles into educational policies and practices? Options: A. people who have a growth mindset believe that intelligence can be developed while people with a fixed mindset believe that intelligence is a fixed trait people with a fixed mindset think of intelligence kind of like eye color they believe that you're born with a certain amount of intelligence and you can't do much to change that people with the growth mindset think of intelligence more like a muscle they understand that when you put in effort and challenge yourself you can get smarter just just like when you put an effort at the gym and challenge Yourself by lifting heavier weights to make your muscle stronger think about this statement you can learn new things but you can't really change your basic intelligence people who really agree with this statement have a fixed mindset people who really disagree with this statement have a growth mindset and of course people might be somewhere in the middle it turns out that the more students disagree with statements like these the more they have a growth mindset the better they do in school this is because students with a growth mindset approach School differently than students with the fixed mindset they have different goals in school the main goal for students with a fixed mindset is to show how smart they are or to hide how unintelligent they are this makes sense if you think that intelligence is something you either have or you don't have you want to show that you have it students with a fixed mindset will avoid asking questions when they don't understand something because they want to preserve the image that similarly students with a fixed mindset view effort negatively they think if I have to try I must not be very smart at this while students with a growth mindset view effort as the way that you learn the way that you get smarter where you'll really see a difference in students with fixed and growth mindsets is when they are faced with a challenge or setback students with a fixed mindset will give up because they think their setback means they're not smart but students with a growth mindset actually like challenges if they already knew how to do something it wouldn't be an opportunity to learn to develop their intelligence given that students with a growth mindset try harder in school especially in the face of a challenge it's no surprise they do better in school

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.
